_header: When ended was my tale of Melibee
Title(s): Monk’s Prologue; ‘Words of the Host to the Monk’; Canterbury Tales
_description: Geoffrey Chaucer, the Monk’s Prologue of the Canterbury Tales — 102 lines in rhyming couplets.

BodArcSelB14.First Lines:
Whan ended was this tale of Mellibeand of Prudence & hir
                    benignite…
BodArcSelB14.Last Lines:
…as it cometh now to my remembrauncehaue me excused of myn
                    ignoraunce
BodArcSelB14.Attributed Title:
Here endith Chauncers his tale of Mellibe / and Prudence And next sueth the
                    Monkis prolog (f. 193v); the Monkes prolog (RT); Here endith the
                    Monke his prolog… (f. 195)

BodBar20.Last Lines:

                    ignorance
BodBar20.Attributed Title:

                    tale (f. 232); Here endith / þe tale… (f. 233v)

                    benygnyte…

                    prolog of Monk (f. 243v, foot)

GULHun197.Transcription:
Whanne ended was þe tale of melobius & prudenceOure Ooste
                    swore by goddys dere pacienceI had leuer thanne a barel of aleThat
                    Goodlief my wife herde this tale
GULHun197.Note:
These lines, adapted from Monk’s Prologue, are written as a
                    heading; Nun’s Priest’s Tale (142) follows in this
                    MS, without a prologue.
